title: GSA of a simple Gaussian model
text: Global Sensitivity Analysis goal breaking mathematical model’s tough rind, allowing us look inside. Let’s assume modeling problem two quantities interest, 𝐘={Y1,Y2}\mathbf{Y} = \{Y_1, Y_2\}, defined function three variables, 𝐗=(X1,X2,X3)\mathbf{X} = (X_1, X_2, X_3). express dependence linear transformation 𝐘=A𝐗\mathbf{Y} = \mathbf{X}, =[42325−1]. = \begin{bmatrix}       4 & 2 & 3 \\       2 & 5 & -1      \end{bmatrix}.  assume inputs uncertain uncertainty can modeled using multivariate normal distribution, 𝐗∼𝒩(𝛍,Σ)\mathbf{X} \sim \mathcal{N}(\mathbf{\mu}, \Sigma), μ=(1,1,1)\mu = (1,1,1) Σ=[10.50.50.510.50.50.51]. \Sigma = \begin{bmatrix}             1 & 0.5 & 0.5 \\             0.5 & 1 & 0.5 \\             0.5 & 0.5 & 1           \end{bmatrix}.  perform uncertainty quantification model, assumed distribution inputs, can use simple Monte Carlo simulation. generate input sample (x), estimate model output (y) input. can define model simulate R using following code block. can plot distribution output using ggplot2 package.
code: # Define the input distribution parameters mx <- c(1, 1, 1) Sigmax <- matrix(data = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1), nrow = 3)  # Define the number of samples N <- 1000  # Set the random number generator seed for reproducibility set.seed(777)  # Sample from standard normals x1 <- rnorm(N) x2 <- rnorm(N) x3 <- rnorm(N)  # Transform the standard normals into the required distribution x <- cbind(x1, x2, x3) x <- mx + x %*% chol(Sigmax)  # Define the model (matrix with coefficients) A <- matrix(data = c(4, -2, 1, 2, 5, -1), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)  # Generate the output y <- t(A %*% t(x)) colnames(y) <- c("y1", "y2") library(ggplot2) #> Error in get(paste0(generic, ".", class), envir = get_method_env()) :  #>   object 'type_sum.accel' not found library(patchwork)  # Set the theme theme_set(theme_minimal())  # Prepare the marginal and the 2D density plots p1 <- ggplot(as.data.frame(y), aes(x = y1, y = y2)) +   geom_point(color = "black") +   geom_density_2d() p2 <- ggplot(as.data.frame(y), aes(x = y1)) +   geom_density() p3 <- ggplot(as.data.frame(y), aes(x = y2)) +   geom_density() +   coord_flip()  p2 + plot_spacer() + p1 + p3 +   plot_layout(ncol = 2, nrow = 2, widths = c(4, 1), heights = c(1, 4), axes = "collect")

title: GSA of a simple Gaussian model
text: Given uncertainty, interested knowing important inputs model. goal package gsaot designed . package, can compute different indices evaluate importance inputs different statistical properties output. Let’s first compute Wasserstein-Bures sensitivity indices. Since inputs outputs gaussians, indices actual solution Optimal Transport problem . However, usually case. hyperparameter needed case number partitions input data, M. set value 25 since 1000 data points. can also use package functions create plots indices.  estimate uncertainty indices, can use bootstrapping. implemented function ot_indices_wb option boot = TRUE. case, also set number replicas (R).
code: library(gsaot)  M <- 25 indices_wb <- ot_indices_wb(x, y, M) indices_wb #> Method: wasserstein-bures  #>  #> Indices: #>        V1        V2        V3  #> 0.4951390 0.5072342 0.1387523  #>  #> Advective component: #>        V1        V2        V3  #> 0.3030834 0.3214758 0.1209107  #>  #> Diffusive component: #>        V1        V2        V3  #> 0.1920556 0.1857584 0.0178415  #>  #> Upper bound: 94.73206 plot(indices_wb) # Enable bootstrap boot <- TRUE # Set the number of replicas R <- 100 # Define the confidence level conf <- 0.99 # Define the type of confidence interval type <- "norm"  # Compute the indices indices_wb <- ot_indices_wb(x, y, M,                              boot = boot, R = R, conf = conf, type = type) plot(indices_wb)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Leonardo Chiani. Author, maintainer, copyright holder. Emanuele Borgonovo. Reviewer. Elmar Plischke. Reviewer. Massimo Tavoni. Reviewer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Chiani L (2024). gsaot: Compute Global Sensitivity Analysis Indices Using Optimal Transport. R package version 0.1.0, https://pietrocipolla.github.io/gsaot/, https://github.com/pietrocipolla/gsaot.
code: @Manual{,   title = {gsaot: Compute Global Sensitivity Analysis Indices Using Optimal Transport},   author = {Leonardo Chiani},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.1.0, https://pietrocipolla.github.io/gsaot/},   url = {https://github.com/pietrocipolla/gsaot}, }

what: Compute Global Sensitivity Analysis Indices Using Optimal Transport
title: Compute Global Sensitivity Analysis Indices Using Optimal Transport
text: package gsaot provides set tools compute plot Optimal Transport (OT) based sensitivity indices. core functions package : ot_indices(): compute OT indices multivariate outputs using different solvers OT (network simplex, Sinkhorn, ). ot_indices_wb(): compute OT indices univariate multivariate outputs using Wasserstein-Bures semi-metric. ot_indices_1d(): compute OT indices univariate outputs using OT solution one dimension. package provides also functions plot resulting indices inner statistics.

title: Compute Global Sensitivity Analysis Indices Using Optimal Transport
text: can install development version gsaot GitHub :
code: install.packages("gsaot") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("pietrocipolla/gsaot")

title: Compute Global Sensitivity Analysis Indices Using Optimal Transport
text: sinkhorn sinkhorn_log solvers gsaot greatly benefit optimization compilation. add option (package installation), edit .R/Makevars file desired flags. Even though different compilers different options, common flag enable safe level optimization detailed information customize R packages compilation can found R guide.
code: CXXFLAGS+=-O2

title: Compute Global Sensitivity Analysis Indices Using Optimal Transport
text: can use gaussian toy model three outputs example: defined number partitions, compute sensitivity indices using different solvers. First, Sinkhorn solver default parameters: Second, Network Simplex solver: Third, Wasserstein-Bures solver, bootstrap: Fourth, can use package compute sensitivity map output:
code: library(gsaot)  N <- 1000  mx <- c(1, 1, 1) Sigmax <- matrix(data = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1), nrow = 3)  x1 <- rnorm(N) x2 <- rnorm(N) x3 <- rnorm(N)  x <- cbind(x1, x2, x3) x <- mx + x %*% chol(Sigmax)  A <- matrix(data = c(4, -2, 1, 2, 5, -1), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) y <- t(A %*% t(x))  x <- data.frame(x) M <- 25  sensitivity_indices <- ot_indices(x, y, M) #> Using default values for solver sinkhorn sensitivity_indices #> Method: sinkhorn  #>  #> Indices: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.5656021 0.6131907 0.2594603  #>  #> Upper bound: 97.74799 sensitivity_indices <- ot_indices(x, y, M, solver = "transport") #> Using default values for solver transport sensitivity_indices #> Method: transport  #>  #> Indices: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.4878673 0.5265048 0.1709062  #>  #> Upper bound: 97.74799 sensitivity_indices <- ot_indices_wb(x, y, M, boot = TRUE, R = 100) sensitivity_indices #> Method: wasserstein-bures  #>  #> Indices: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.4591200 0.4921479 0.1073590  #>  #> Advective component: #>         X1         X2         X3  #> 0.28001929 0.31345309 0.09888083  #>  #> Diffusive component: #>          X1          X2          X3  #> 0.179100703 0.178694835 0.008478178  #>  #> Type of confidence interval: norm  #> Number of replicates: 100  #> Confidence level: 0.95  #> Indices confidence intervals: #>   Inputs     Index      low.ci    high.ci #> 1     X1        WB 0.439721916 0.47851807 #> 2     X2        WB 0.475448734 0.50884711 #> 3     X3        WB 0.087350066 0.12736794 #> 4     X1 Advective 0.267679667 0.29235891 #> 5     X2 Advective 0.303581126 0.32332505 #> 6     X3 Advective 0.081559278 0.11620237 #> 7     X1 Diffusive 0.170346138 0.18785527 #> 8     X2 Diffusive 0.170261391 0.18712828 #> 9     X3 Diffusive 0.003887014 0.01306934 #>  #> Upper bound: 97.85844 sensitivity_indices <- ot_indices_smap(x, y, M) sensitivity_indices #>             X1         X2        X3 #> [1,] 0.5744058 0.04464331 0.1685419 #> [2,] 0.2909957 0.71343703 0.1274479

what: Calculate lower bounds for Optimal Transport sensitivity indices — lower_bound
title: Calculate lower bounds for Optimal Transport sensitivity indices — lower_bound
text: Calculate lower bounds Optimal Transport sensitivity indices

title: Calculate lower bounds for Optimal Transport sensitivity indices — lower_bound
code: lower_bound(   y,   M,   bound = "dummy",   dummy_optns = NULL,   cost = "L2",   discrete_out = FALSE,   solver = "sinkhorn",   solver_optns = NULL,   scaling = TRUE )

title: Calculate lower bounds for Optimal Transport sensitivity indices — lower_bound
text: y array matrix containing output values. M scalar representing number partitions continuous inputs. bound (default "dummy") string defining type lower bound compute. "dummy" "entropic". See details information. dummy_optns (default NULL) list containing options distribution dummy variable. See details information. cost (default "L2") string function defining cost function Optimal Transport problem. "L2" function taking input y returning cost matrix. cost="L2", ot_indices uses squared Euclidean metric. discrete_out (default FALSE) Logical, default output sample y equally weighted. discrete_out=TRUE, function tries create histogram realizations use histogram weights. works output discrete mixed number realizations large. advantage option reduce dimension cost matrix. solver Solver Optimal Transport problem. Currently supported options : "sinkhorn" (default), Sinkhorn's solver cuturi2013sinkhorngsaot. "sinkhorn_log", Sinkhorn's solver log scale peyre2019computationalgsaot. "transport", solver non regularized OT problem using transport::transport(). solver_optns (optional) list containing options Optimal Transport solver. See details allowed options default ones. scaling (default TRUE) Logical sets whether scale cost matrix.

title: Calculate lower bounds for Optimal Transport sensitivity indices — lower_bound
text: object class gsaot_indices bound="dummy" scalar bound="entropic".

title: Calculate lower bounds for Optimal Transport sensitivity indices — lower_bound
text: function allows computation two different lower bounds. bound="dummy", function samples distribution defined dummy_optns (default standard normal), independent output y computes indices using algorithm specified solver. hood, lower_bound calls available functions package: ot_indices_1d() (solver="1d) ot_indices_wb() (solver="wasserstein-bures") ot_indices() (solver %% c("sinkhorn", "sinkhorn_log", "wasserstein")) user can choose distribution dummy variable using argument dummy_optns. dummy_optns named list least term called "distr" defining sampling function. terms list used arguments sampling function. bound="entropic", function computes lower bound entropic indices. case, solver either "sinkhorn" "sinkhorn_log"

title: Calculate lower bounds for Optimal Transport sensitivity indices — lower_bound
code: N <- 1000  mx <- c(1, 1, 1) Sigmax <- matrix(data = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1), nrow = 3)  x1 <- rnorm(N) x2 <- rnorm(N) x3 <- rnorm(N)  x <- cbind(x1, x2, x3) x <- mx + x %*% chol(Sigmax)  A <- matrix(data = c(4, -2, 1, 2, 5, -1), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) y <- t(A %*% t(x))  M <- 25  sink_lb <- lower_bound(y, M, bound = "entropic") dummy_lb <- lower_bound(y, M, bound = "dummy")  # Custom sampling funtion and network simplex solver dummy_optns <- list(distr = "rgamma", shape = 3) dummy_lb_cust <- lower_bound(y, M, bound = "dummy",                                   dummy_optns = dummy_optns,                                   solver = "transport")

what: Calculate Optimal Transport sensitivity indices for multivariate y — ot_indices
title: Calculate Optimal Transport sensitivity indices for multivariate y — ot_indices
text: ot_indices calculates sensitivity indices using Optimal Transport (OT) multivariate output sample y respect input data x. Sensitivity indices measure influence inputs outputs, values ranging 0 1.

title: Calculate Optimal Transport sensitivity indices for multivariate y — ot_indices
code: ot_indices(   x,   y,   M,   cost = "L2",   discrete_out = FALSE,   solver = "sinkhorn",   solver_optns = NULL,   scaling = TRUE,   boot = FALSE,   stratified_boot = FALSE,   R = NULL,   parallel = "no",   ncpus = 1,   conf = 0.95,   type = "norm" )

title: Calculate Optimal Transport sensitivity indices for multivariate y — ot_indices
text: x matrix data.frame containing input(s) values. values can numeric, factors, strings. type data changes partitioning. values continuous (double), function partitions data M sets. values discrete (integers, strings, factors), number partitioning sets data-driven. y matrix containing output values. column represents different output variable, row represents different observation. numeric values allowed. M scalar representing number partitions continuous inputs. cost (default "L2") string function defining cost function Optimal Transport problem. "L2" function taking input y returning cost matrix. cost="L2", ot_indices uses squared Euclidean metric. discrete_out (default FALSE) Logical, default output sample y equally weighted. discrete_out=TRUE, function tries create histogram realizations use histogram weights. works output discrete mixed number realizations large. advantage option reduce dimension cost matrix. solver Solver Optimal Transport problem. Currently supported options : "sinkhorn" (default), Sinkhorn's solver cuturi2013sinkhorngsaot. "sinkhorn_log", Sinkhorn's solver log scale peyre2019computationalgsaot. "transport", solver non regularized OT problem using transport::transport(). solver_optns (optional) list containing options Optimal Transport solver. See details allowed options default ones. scaling (default TRUE) Logical sets whether scale cost matrix. boot (default FALSE) Logical sets whether perform bootstrapping OT indices. stratified_boot (default FALSE) Logical sets type resampling performed. stratified_boot=FALSE, function resamples dataset creates partitions. Otherwise, first, creates partitions performs stratified bootstrapping strata partitions. R (default NULL) Positive integer, number bootstrap replicas. parallel (default "") type parallel operation used (). missing, default taken option boot.parallel (set, ""). considered boot = TRUE. information, check boot::boot() function. ncpus (default 1) Positive integer: number processes used parallel operation: typically one chose number available CPUs. Check ncpus option boot::boot() function boot package. conf (default 0.95) Number 0 1 representing confidence level. considered boot = TRUE. type (default "norm") Method compute confidence interval. considered boot = TRUE. information, check type option boot::boot.ci().

title: Calculate Optimal Transport sensitivity indices for multivariate y — ot_indices
text: gsaot_indices object containing: method: string identifies type indices computed. indices: names array containing sensitivity indices 0 1 column x, indicating influence input variable output variables. bound: double representing upper bound separation measure array representing mean separation input according bootstrap replicas. x, y: input output data provided arguments function. inner_statistic: list matrices containing values inner statistics partitions defined partitions. method = wasserstein-bures, matrix three rows containing Wasserstein-Bures indices, Advective, Diffusive components. partitions: matrix containing partitions built calculate sensitivity indices. column contains partition associated column x. boot = TRUE, object contains also: indices_ci: data.frame first column input, second third columns lower upper bound confidence interval. inner_statistic_ci: list matrices. element list contains lower upper confidence bounds partition defined row. bound_ci: list containing lower upper bounds confidence intervals separation measure bound. type, conf: type confidence interval confidence level, provided arguments.

title: Calculate Optimal Transport sensitivity indices for multivariate y — ot_indices
text: OT widely studied topic Operational Research Calculus. reference OT solvers package peyre2019computational;textualgsaot. default solver "sinkhorn", Sinkhorn's solver introduced cuturi2013sinkhorn;textualgsaot. solves entropic-regularized version OT problem. "sinkhorn_log" solves OT problem log scale. stable low values regularization parameter slower converge. option "transport" used choose solver non-regularized OT problem. hood, function calls transport::transport() package transport. option define solver per se, solver defined argument solver_optns. See next section information.

title: Calculate Optimal Transport sensitivity indices for multivariate y — ot_indices
text: argument solver_optns empty (default options) list required solver parameters. parameters included list set default values. solvers "sinkhorn" "sinkhorn_log" options: numIterations (default 1e3): positive integer defining maximum number Sinkhorn's iterations allowed. solver converge number iterations set, solver throw error. epsilon (default 0.01): positive real number defining regularization coefficient. value low, solver may return NA. maxErr (default 1e-9): positive real number defining approximation error threshold marginal histogram partition one computed solver. solver may fail converge numIterations value low. solver "transport" parameters: method (default "networkflow): string defining solver OT problem. control: named list parameters chosen method result call transport::trcontrol(). threads (default 1): Integer specifying number threads used parallel computing. details regarding solver, check transport::transport() help page.

title: Calculate Optimal Transport sensitivity indices for multivariate y — ot_indices
code: N <- 1000  mx <- c(1, 1, 1) Sigmax <- matrix(data = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1), nrow = 3)  x1 <- rnorm(N) x2 <- rnorm(N) x3 <- rnorm(N)  x <- cbind(x1, x2, x3) x <- mx + x %*% chol(Sigmax)  A <- matrix(data = c(4, -2, 1, 2, 5, -1), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) y <- t(A %*% t(x))  x <- data.frame(x)  M <- 25  # Calculate sensitivity indices sensitivity_indices <- ot_indices(x, y, M) sensitivity_indices #> Method: sinkhorn  #>  #> Solver Options: #> $numIterations #> [1] 1000 #>  #> $epsilon #> [1] 0.01 #>  #> $maxErr #> [1] 1e-09 #>  #>  #> Indices: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.5982222 0.6120543 0.2761801  #>  #> Upper bound: 95.02202

title: Evaluate Wasserstein-Bures approximation of the Optimal Transport solution — ot_indices_wb
text: gsaot_indices object containing: method: string identifies type indices computed. indices: names array containing sensitivity indices 0 1 column x, indicating influence input variable output variables. bound: double representing upper bound separation measure array representing mean separation input according bootstrap replicas. x, y: input output data provided arguments function. inner_statistic: list matrices containing values inner statistics partitions defined partitions. method = wasserstein-bures, matrix three rows containing Wasserstein-Bures indices, Advective, Diffusive components. partitions: matrix containing partitions built calculate sensitivity indices. column contains partition associated column x. boot = TRUE, object contains also: indices_ci: data.frame first column input, second third columns lower upper bound confidence interval. inner_statistic_ci: list matrices. element list contains lower upper confidence bounds partition defined row. bound_ci: list containing lower upper bounds confidence intervals separation measure bound. type, conf: type confidence interval confidence level, provided arguments.

title: Evaluate Wasserstein-Bures approximation of the Optimal Transport solution — ot_indices_wb
code: N <- 1000  mx <- c(1, 1, 1) Sigmax <- matrix(data = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1), nrow = 3)  x1 <- rnorm(N) x2 <- rnorm(N) x3 <- rnorm(N)  x <- cbind(x1, x2, x3) x <- mx + x %*% chol(Sigmax)  A <- matrix(data = c(4, -2, 1, 2, 5, -1), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) y <- t(A %*% t(x))  x <- data.frame(x) y <- y  ot_indices_wb(x, y, 100) #> Method: wasserstein-bures  #>  #> Indices: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.5270767 0.5380900 0.1831289  #>  #> Advective component: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.3143543 0.3362151 0.1423724  #>  #> Diffusive component: #>         X1         X2         X3  #> 0.21272243 0.20187498 0.04075641  #>  #> Upper bound: 92.57906

title: Plot Optimal Transport sensitivity indices — plot.gsaot_indices
code: N <- 1000  mx <- c(1, 1, 1) Sigmax <- matrix(data = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1), nrow = 3)  x1 <- rnorm(N) x2 <- rnorm(N) x3 <- rnorm(N)  x <- cbind(x1, x2, x3) x <- mx + x %*% chol(Sigmax)  A <- matrix(data = c(4, -2, 1, 2, 5, -1), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) y <- t(A %*% t(x))  x <- data.frame(x)  M <- 25  # Calculate sensitivity indices sensitivity_indices <- ot_indices_wb(x, y, M) sensitivity_indices #> Method: wasserstein-bures  #>  #> Indices: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.4884653 0.4921685 0.1319275  #>  #> Advective component: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.2959886 0.3113776 0.1149829  #>  #> Diffusive component: #>         X1         X2         X3  #> 0.19247673 0.18079086 0.01694463  #>  #> Upper bound: 96.6074   plot(sensitivity_indices)

title: Print Optimal Transport Sensitivity indices information — print.gsaot_indices
code: N <- 1000  mx <- c(1, 1, 1) Sigmax <- matrix(data = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5, 1), nrow = 3)  x1 <- rnorm(N) x2 <- rnorm(N) x3 <- rnorm(N)  x <- cbind(x1, x2, x3) x <- mx + x %*% chol(Sigmax)  A <- matrix(data = c(4, -2, 1, 2, 5, -1), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE) y <- t(A %*% t(x))  x <- data.frame(x)  M <- 25  # Calculate sensitivity indices sensitivity_indices <- ot_indices(x, y, M) print(sensitivity_indices) #> Method: sinkhorn  #>  #> Solver Options: #> $numIterations #> [1] 1000 #>  #> $epsilon #> [1] 0.01 #>  #> $maxErr #> [1] 1e-09 #>  #>  #> Indices: #>        X1        X2        X3  #> 0.5867669 0.6233498 0.2791924  #>  #> Upper bound: 92.56641
